address: 7030 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 5 Singapore 569880 Singapore
comment: This place is very well hidden at the back lanes of a industrial building.  Nonetheless the crowd keeps streaming for their meals even at night. Hence the food standard is suspected to be good. Horfun is one of the delicacy here and hence the standard of evaluation is higher without doubt. I hv ordered a medium packet of houfun with excitement and anxiety as rumor was that it taste great here. The verdict unfortunately was not up to my liking.  It lack the "wok hei" smell (slight burnt smell but not charred) that I missed for years though the ingredients were plentiful.

address: 7030 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 5 Singapore 569880 Singapore
comment: Located at North Star which is an automotive industrial estate, you can't miss it, tons of tyre shops, at the back of it facing amk ave 5 is Rongji seafood, moved from jalan kayu to this even more ulu locationWaited 1hr 30 mins for the food to be served and every dish was laden with sugar which had me reaching for my drink every mouthful!! The deer meat was okay, but it was drenched in oil. It was tender but you had to dig for the meat under layers of onion.. The ngoh hiang was okay.. Nothing to rave about..The claypot fish was too sweet, I did enjoy the cabbage and pork in there and everyone commented that the fish head was huge.The veggies were also drenched in oil with dried onions sprinkled on top.The lor bak or thick fat pork was so so, the sauce was too sweet.The spicy fried sotong was super sweet which killed my throat. I'm suffering now from this meal.All in all for $125 for each table of 8-9 people it is dirt cheap but the wait was so long, my aunty had to take gastric pills whilst waiting. And the food is just terrible. They are famous for their crabs but they had run out. But I will not give this place another go. It's just terrible.When we asked for two baby chairs, a grumpy aunty gave me a stern look and said, go find yourself..  Really? Is it that hard? We had two babies at the table!

address: 7030 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 5 Singapore 569880 Singapore
comment: My first visit to Rong Ji, very disappointed.  My sister & her friend recommended us to go there for good crabs. We ordered 3 crabs, 1 veg, 1 fish & 1 prawn paste chicken. They came back saying prawn paste chicken sold out. As we dig into the first black pepper crab, noticed that the meat shrunken. You see very big claw but when you break the shell the meat is only half the size. Moving on to the 2nd chilli crab, same thing, 3rd butter crab even smaller. Steam fish taste great! All in $306, they gave us $6 discount for the crabs issue. :(We walk all the way to the front to ask them to help pack the left over crabs, they told us to bring all the plates back ourselves in order for them to pack for us.  They did help to pack our food only when we ask them to come collect the payment.Their cooking is quite good but my crab feast is a total flop.

Very very old school. When you come in, you feel like you are almost transported to the 1980s or a Hong Kong cafe movie set. The coin operated orange telephone reminds you of that. The squeaky bench that hadn't been replaced in decades had some flying insect lurking around. Because I was transported back in time, it seems like that can be forgiven. The food came... rice was flavourful, not too oily and just not as mushy as I expected. It was good. The chicken is not as tender as what you'd have at Tian Tian of course. But it is still very smooth. A little gelatinous chicken fat falls into the sauce. We ordered a $10 portion for two persons instead of the $8 and they were honest. Portions ain't too small. (They were flexible to accommodate whatever price for your chicken portion). The soups were also good recommendations. At $3 its almost too good to be true with two persons sharing. All the soups here are generally good. But I do have doubts why they add raw cabbages into it. As if to say this is old school and we do not care why. Then the surprising stunner. Bittergourd with eggs stir fried. It was awesome. We gobbled it all up. It was cooked so well we can't explain it. You still tastes the slight bitterness of the bittergourd but the eggs and sauce neutralises it to the degree that you do not mind. When comes the time for the bill, an old lady with a wide smile came over to us to bid us goodbye as if to say she will be here stuck in time till our next visit, in that time capsule restaurant, while we move on to the future. 5 stars for the nostalgia and the food that pairs with it.
One very grouchy staff (others ok) but the food more than makes up for this.  We get takeaways most of the time.

Having grown up in the neighbourhood since the late 60s, my family and I have been coming here for ages.I enjoy the chicken rice here.Very succulent meat and not too oily.The rice that accompanies the chicken is quite flavorful.I like that you can also order some other Hainanese dishes like the chicken chop and vegetables.I also find it 'cute' that they still calculate the bill the old school way where they come to the table and count your dishes...

Made me nostalgic for the chicken rice of the good old days. The owners and the no-frills interior of the restaurant harken back to the mom & pop street shop days. The chicken rice was also no-frills, just simply and quietly providing that fuzzy comforting feeling. Nothing more and nothing less was needed.Many tables seemed to be ordering the chestnut drink, so I figured why not. It was a refreshing complement to the lunch meal and helped to cool down from the blistering heat outside.The loofah vegetable dish was also very tasty (and as good as it looks in the Yelp photo), so definitely try that if you can!

Not to be confused with the famous Wee Nam Kee found opposite Novena square/Velocity, Nam Kee is a traditional Hainanese chicken rice restaurant as well. I visited Nam Kee Chicken Rice as part of a birthday celebration of a family member. While the furnishings were old (round wooden tables and plastic chairs), the restaurant was air-conditioned. We were tended to by an elderly lady who spoke mandarin and dialect. Aside from the usual chicken rice, they served a variety of Chinese dishes, or "zi char" as Singaporeans term it. All the dishes have a home cooked feel and flavor. We ordered omelette with onion, ngoh hiang, half a chicken, sambal kang kong, stir fried broccoli. The chicken rice was not too oily and light tasting as well, which contributes to the making of good chicken rice.The total bill came up to be 60. Quick math revealed that it was roughly 8 to 9 dollars per pax for an especially filling meal (each had several extra bowls of rice). A word of advise is to not park at road beside the restaurant as it is usually filled up and narrow, not to mention that it is parallel parking. It would be better to park further ahead at the HDB nearby or even at Thomson Plaza before walking over

Nam Kee Chicken Rice is a coffee shop with a simple and rather traditional set-up along Upper Thomson Road that has been known for its chicken rice for quite some time now. The first time I had it, I was not impressed but I returned a second time as my dad wanted to give it a try. They serve a variety of dishes besides the usual chicken and rice and we got a plate of fried kangkong in addition to the chicken rice. The crowd at Nam Kee Chicken Rice is rather misleading. One would think they do really great chicken rice judging from the number of people waiting for a table. Unfortunately, the chicken rice was not satisfactory the 2 times I've eaten there. While the chicken is nice and tender, the portion was really small for 2 people. The rice was what totally changed my impression of the stall. It was mushy and broken and the flavour was bland.I find Nam Kee Chicken Rice pretty over-rated. There are many better and possibly cheaper stalls out there.

I have been working out of office for two days straight now to get some quiet time to plan and reflect. Yahava is one top of my list forcomfortable place to sit and do some  work while sipping great coffee. No other coffee place can beat them for the taste and price. Try anything on the list- I'm pretty sure that it will be great. They also supply beans to several others places so you can even buy some of the beans back home. The food/dessert offerings are alright. However, with Awfully Chocolate, Ice Cream Chef, and the hawker centre a stone throw away, I would prefer to just order coffee here. Since It's not easy to come here, the place doesn't get too crowded on most days. They don't offer free wifi or charging point (that I know of), so come with a fully charged laptop. Alternatively, just sit back, sip on the great coffee and read a book.

Settled in an industrial estate right behind around my neighbourhood is this speciality coffee shop. My friends said they tried their coffee in Perth and loved it. I wish there was more food selection but a scone $4 nicely heated up served up as a delicious breakfast with a fragrant cup of coffee!

Read about this place on a cafe hunter's blog and hence I sought it out.The only cafe I had visited that listed the controversial Flat White right at the top of its coffee offering!!!! The coffee was really really good, in the sense that I did not noticed I had finished off my cup so quickly without realizing it! I was alone. The rain outside just started. Either the cup was smaller than my usual or that the coffee was indeed too good for me to notice my greedy gulps (I swear I thought I was sipping :(). My cuppa break was accompanied by a slice of banana bread, which was tasty and delightfully moist despite its look.Alas the service staff were too zoned out to make me feel embraced. The place was relatively big but emotionless.

Nice hidden quiet coffee place with stellar coffee! This place which can be a little out of the way, but that's what makes it a nice place to chill. Excellent cappuccino and other regular coffees for a reasonable price with no fancy gimmicks. Would reccomend the chai latte($5/5.50/6)-literally the best I've tasted! Nothing like Starbucks/Coffee bean/Cedele. You've never tasted chai till you taste this, really. A great place to hang out with family on weekends/weekday afternoons :)

Full stars for my favourite coffee place in Singapore. This is a place which you go strictly for the coffee. I am not vouching for the food which happens to be limited in variety. My favourite beans include X-rated (or was it triple X?), Dark Gold and Romeo. Give me a skinny flat white please!

My usual coffee place. Since I work near Yahava, for the past 3 years, my daily dosage and beans all coming from them. While they have 8-10 beans that are always available, Yahava will bring in exotic beans once a month. A side note, it is affliated with the Yahava in Australia. Highly recommended for people who stay in the north-central area of Singapore to give Yahava a visit. Of course, if you are a coffee lover.

For those coffee lovers this is a must try as they serve excellent coffee made from beans that they got from Bali. This is not your average cafe as from what i heard their aim is actually to distribute the beans to individual folks and companies to promote it and not really to run a cafe business.I decided to try the cappuccino as that is what i normally drank elsewhere. It had a nice and strong aroma yet the amount of acidity in that cup was not very high thus not leaving a sour aftertaste which i hate. The milk that they added was really nice too and made the coffee all the more yummy to drink, and it left a nice aroma in my mouth after.Service there was average but i would definitely go back for more coffee. They do have some decor on the coffee too using the foam they dash on top of it.

yeeehaaaa! finally a decent koffee place in my hood. ive been here 5 times and let's just say ive not been disappointed with their koffee. it has the omph factor and perks me up good. only other thing ive tried was their torte choc tart. it was OK, portion was really small for e price, guess that helped me save some calories.ambience is cosy with soft lighting and jazzy background music. perfect place to chill out on a weekday arvo if you want peace away from e hustle and bustle from town. its also good for families with two couches setup near a small play area for kids. not a huge play area, all i see is a wooden house with few boxes of lego blocks. enough to keep your little ones busy while ure having a cuppa  :)best part for koffee lovers, they have free koffee tasting everyday from 9am - 5pm, selecting from more than 14 varieties. *** barista was especially nice today and made me a bearie cute cappuccino. totally made my day. :D im a sucker for koffee art.

Visited Yahava Koffee works on a Sunday morning following  along cycle ride. The coffee shop has a very nice feel. I ordered a strong flat white and a waffle with I cream. The flat white was very good, probably one of the best I've had in Singapore. The waffle was very well cooked. Key issue for me is the $1 extra charge for a very small amount of Maple syrup. One would expect the maple syrup to be complimentary given waffles aren't compete without maple syrup

Along the stretch of the Sembawang Hill shophouses, lies this rather hidden cafe in this quiet estate. Being a franchise of the Australian outlet, you can expect the same services you get from there, here. That means, different types of coffee from all around the world and free coffee tasting! The Flat White tasted great. It is rather thick and with the right amount of milk added, produces a coffee taste that is not too overwhelming.The Carrot Cake is flavourful and slightly crumbly. Soft on the inside, crumbly on the outside.For a quiet place to study and relax or talk about work, this place offers the environment to do so (and with its great coffee and cakes!).

This little gem is hidden in my neighbourhood and I didn't even know till I chanced upon its banner one day. The coffee is very robust in flavour and texture is full bodied. I tried the latte and the mocha. I am floored by the mocha as this one is the real deal. The chocolately, malty flavour of the mocha comes from the coffee not chocolate syrup. On the downside, the place doesn't serve any hot or cooked food. It serves mainly sweets like muffins, cakes and pies. They have a limited range of sandwiches which are pre-packed.

This Germanish place is outstanding value, and has good quality food. It isn't even inaccessible either, being a stone's throw from Kovan MRT, albeit hidden behind some HDB blocks.The interior design is reminiscent of a place that should cost at least 50% more. Sitting inside, I could almost imagine I was in Holland Village.The clam chowder was $5 and was alright - nothing special but still decent.Pork schnitzel was $8 and was crispy, juicy and tasty. It came with creamy mushroom sauce which I suspect wasn't authentic, but it was tasty. And the portion was bigger than I expected for the price.The pork knuckle was $10. The skin was very crispy. The meat was alright if a bit dry  - it could be a bit more tender and moister. It also could've come with a bit more sauce.Earlier I described this place as Germanish rather than German. Among other things that's because they only had one type of sausage. And chicken sausage at that. But it's homemade...There isn't any air conditioning and they only accept cash. But at least you know they're cutting overheads in those departments (they don't charge GST or service either).

I'm a bit surprised that this place was not on Yelp's listing since it's been around for quite some time now. Knuckles serves the CHEAPEST pork knuckles in town at just 10 dollars. They also don't cut corners but serve you a really good dish. If you prefer a whole knuckle, that would cost you just $30 dollars. The owner also mentioned that all his burgers are made with quality meat. Home made stuff and not frozen patties. I would have tried if we had not ordered two mains already. Will definitely be back to try it soon. If you are in the area,want to try cheap Western/German good, and don't want to queue, do try Knuckles. Lots of beer selection. You get to sip your cold beer and chill while watching people queuing up for Nakorn Thai food next door. No GST no service charge. And open till late.
Good food! But prepare to queue. Beef steak was great. Pork knuckle is good too. But only cash payment available

address: 48A Tanglin Halt Road #01-14 Tanglin Halt Market Singapore 142048 Singapore
comment: Located in a popular coffee shop with a number of more famous stalls but I was craving for lor mee so decided to give it a try. To be honest, I was almost put off by the window display since the ingredients seemed rather sparse and messy. I was pleasantly surprised that the taste and portion turned out great. It was a satisfying dish and felt quite home-cooked.

address: 81 Lor Chencharu Orto Park Singapore 769198 Singapore
comment: Every dishes were unique and great.  Came here specifically for the crispy Fire Flame Chicken. Crispy outside,  tender and juicy inside.

chill, so chill. this place is a really nice place to hang out with a glass of wine and your favorite person amidst tables full of people doing the same. the kitchen is surprisingly talented, and churns out some dishes that are pretty wow, and others that still make it past the average mark.we came here on a not-so-hungry stomach, so only managed a couple plates of tapas-like dishes of squid grilled till bouncy. seasoned just nice, and sprinkled with a wedge of lemon - it was eminently edible. as were the garlicky shell-off prawns that were just as tasty (though I think they could have been a little fresher/ meatier).the date pudding was warm cake redolent with the smell of toffee, topped with a thin sort of caramel and served with cold ice cream. very decent rendition of my favorite dessert (though nothing near as good as ps.cafe).it's a quiet place, not helped by its relatively obscure location in maju avenue. that's a double-edged sword, because it helps keep it the sort of neighborhood hangout you want to go to with your partner for a quiet drink, but it also means that business might be difficult to sustain.

We ordered the truffles and forest pizza as well as the seafood linguine. Both were of a generous portion with lots of ingredients. Pizza was thin crust and crispy with loads of mushrooms and gooey cheese. Super messy to eat but oh so good! The linguine was just done with a tomato base with prawns, squid and mussels. The mussels were a tad disappointing (maybe frozen rather than fresh) but overall the pasta was good, albeit we preferred the pizza.
Dinning experience on Level 2 is amazing. Relaxing atmosphere for night out with friends. Pizzas are amazing here.

Discovered Plonk when we were in Serangoon Gardens late at night and most places were already closed. It used to be when you want a drink of the alcoholic type in the area, the options are limited. The pick would be from the coffee shops, karaoke bars or dingy neighborhood pubs which can be quite intimidating. Fast forward to the present, the shops have changed and there are more casual chic and chill out places for drinks and Plonk is definitely new. It is along MyVillage facing the small open air parking lot. It is an open concept with tables and chairs on the sidewalk as well as inside, with no windows or walls to keep people out. It creates an airy and spacious place with a cozier set up on the 2nd level. We took the high table with high chairs as most tables were taken on Friday. I usually dislike high chairs but this place was quite comfortable. The jug of mojito went down well with lots of mint leaves. It can be slightly stronger but for someone who does not drink much, it is good. Refreshing on a warm night. The pizza was the wood fire thin crispy crust type (similar to Skinny Pizza but slightly thicker) and equally good. We chose the one with iberico ham.  It serves regular food, bar bites, tapas and a decent selection of wines, cocktails and beers. I think I may have found a new place for chilling out in my area.

This was my go-to restaurant in Serangoon Gardens. Great food, excellent service and a good choice of wines. Their standard menu, along with their daily specials, sometimes made choosing a little difficult but never disappointed with what I got. Mussels and Sauv Blanc one day, seafood linguini and rose another day and after having the apple crumble for dessert with a lychee martini, I had to go back for that again. Totally recommend this place

Ambience of this place is lovely - so chill and cozy! Their lower level isn't huge, which makes for seemingly more attentive service. I ordered a pizza, a bowl of truffle fries and a deconstructed lemon tart with fried shallot ice cream. The bowl of fries was much bigger than expected, although I couldn't taste much of the truffle. Lemon tart was yummy, however, the combination of fried shallots and vanilla ice cream didn't really work for me. The pizza was delicious though!
Tasty chicken rice and more ! white chicken is good roasted meats are good price is fair! wife love this place , location also good!

Came by for lunch the other day and it was a tasty experience. Wee Nam Kee is a restaurant with A/C and waiter service.Ordered the roast chicken combo with dumplings and vegetables, oyster sauce vegetables, along with a rice and iced tea.Service by the restaurant was prompt from order taking to fulfillment of the order, all within a few minutes!Started off with the dumplings and vegetables in broth and these were tasty. The dumplings had plenty of meat and vegetables inside. The broth was flavorful and the vegetables were fresh.The side of vegetables with oyster sauce was also tasty. Portions were more than sufficient for lunch!The rice was fragrant rice and very tasty.The roast chicken drumstick came out on the cooler side. Previous visit's chicken tasted even better!There is a 5% service charge on top of 7% GST. Prices are higher in the interim due to supply chain challenges.

Wee nam Kee chicken rice pretz for $1.60 a box!!! You can get them here or at NTUC. The chicken rice here is always good, consistency is true here. Generally I get a bowl of wanton soup to go along with the chicken rice as well!

Restaurant had only customers at three tables yet services were slow and inattentive.Ordered a set of chicken meat with rice and soup but the soup did not come. Had to remind the waitress when I had almost finished my food.The food is good but the restaurant services need to innovate and improve. I do not think I am motivated to visit the restaurant again in the near future.

Hainanese chicken rice is a national dish and one of those things you have to have when you visit Singapore. One spot consistently appears on all of the major lists and reviews to find it: Wee Nam Kee. Don't let its multiple locations make it appear like a "chain" and touristy, it is serving up some pretty damn good bites and worth a visit.While I'm no expert on another countries national dish, it was pretty good in my book and I'd go back for more. The chicken was beautifully cooked and the meat moist through it all and its simple flavors were quickly brought out by the fragrant rice filled with ginger and spice from garlic. Add the soy or chili flavored sauces on the side to your liking and your set.The roast meats that you can order weren't too shabby and the sautéed vegetables were pretty delicious (but not worth a 14 hour flight for). Service is quick and efficient, while the line does add a bit of a wait time, it moves at a decent pace. Prices are pretty reasonable so you could enjoy a few dishes to share. The ambiance is simple and loud, so probably not the best for that high-level dinner meeting or that romantic special evening. In a city filled with so many options, would I go back? Heck yeah..it was pretty good and I know I won't be disappointed.

I would come back here every week if I can afford roundtrip airfare is from the US to here. Lol :)It's a good indoor space with AC to have a nice and quick lunch or dinner if you are in town and think outside is too hot or humid.Salt and Pepper CrabGreat flavor to the pepper sauce. I've had this dish three times in Singapore and their sauce is possibly the best.  Word of caution- this is a messy dish.  There is no good way to eat this- your fingers are going to get dirty and sticky so just dive in and take care of business.   The quality of the crab was three star- it felt a little undersized given the price paid.  I'll give the restaurant the benefit of the doubt because it's late in crab season and I've been spoiled by the Dungeness living in San Francisco.    Salty Egg Prawn with Golden Mini BunOMG this is so delicious. A bit sweet and tiny salty, it's perfect sauce for the mini-bunHai-nun White Chicken & RiceMy all-time favorite, Singapore classic dish. You can use garlic and spicy sauce from the table. There are many famous rice & chicken restaurants in Singapore, but this is definitely one of the best!!Green vegetables stir-fried with shrimp paste, it's a bit salty, but it tastes really good with riceBeef her-fen, very tender beef with white width rice flat noodles. If you like rice flat noodles 河粉 and beef. You will definitely like it. There are few boba milk tea (black sugar caramel is my favorite) and dessert place that is right outside of the restaurant. Good way to end the meal for sure.

I love chicken rice and this chain just does it so well.  This location in particular keeps things moving despite being deluged with many customers who, like myself, want some delicious Hainanese chicken rice and the accoutrements that go along with it. :-)

If my latest check-in says I've been here 15x, then I have to give this place 5 Stars. I'm no chicken rice expert although I've eaten my fair share of them in my few months here in SG. The reason I keep returning to WNK as my favorite chxn rice place is simply because it is so delicious. The roast chicken is my favorite because of the nice skin and tender meat pieces. I also prefer that my ginger and chili pastes are separated in separate containers like it is here. I like to make my own concoction. WNK is a well established restaurant and clientele will continue to flock here for their Hainanese dishes. I was amazed to find out that the founder of WNK doesn't even cook at all. Great story, great food.

The best chicken rice I've ever had in my entire life.  Go with the steamed chicken, although the roast chicken comes quite close.  Also, get the kangkung with some sort of balachan sauce as your veggies.  The salted egg yolk ribs are also bomb!!!

My friend took me to try to famous chicken rice near her office. We got there early before the lunch time rush. Definitely a good call to go early since she was in a rush to return to work. The line started to form after noon but we were seated slightly before the rush.Keep in mind that they leave wet naps on the table which will be added to the bill if you use them. The chicken rice was amazing and it came with soup on the side. We also ordered some veggies, BBQ pork and roasted pork.  The chicken was the highlight of the meal and the prices were reasonable.The pork was not outstanding since I have had better elsewhere. The portions were average but it is great that you are not stuffed by the end of the meal. Service was similar to a food court as they moved from one into their own location. I do crave the tender chicken and will come back if I have the chance to return to Singapore.

I love the roast chicken here (juicy meat and crispy skin) and its condiments (chili, ginger and dark soy sauce). The soup is tasty, none of those watered down liquid other places called it as soup. The rice could be better but is good enough for me especially when you put everything together in one mouthful. It blends beautifully without distractions.The dumpling was not bad but not the star. I would have to try the noodle version as recommended by the king of Singapore aka Nik T some day. The place is very noisy and if you are prone to headache, you may want to get it to go instead. The service is very brusque and efficient and one does not really linger over the meal.

Singapore's national dish is Hainanese Chicken Rice and one of those things you have to have when you visit Singapore. Business lunch and wanted local food, so Wee Nam Kee it was - and I was quite happy. The consistent good reviews are for a very good reason - the food is good, you get a lot and service is great. I recommend the boiled white chicken.The chicken was expertly cooked and the meat moist with a simple flavor that is enhanced by the fragrant rice that has ginger and garlic. Mix the ginger, soy or chili flavored sauces that are on the table for different flavors.
Get the white chicken version, that's their speciality. The sambal version gang kung is good side dish. I would skip the fried dish

I love this restaurant. The hainan chicken rice is so good. I ordered the soya sauce, roast, steamed chicken, bbq pork, and roast pork..taste really good..the oyster sauce vegetables is also good. CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!!

I wonder why this place is so famous. The chicken is pretty good, but not the best Singapore can produce, and the rice is not very fragrant and just average. Other dishes we had  (tofu, salted egg prawns, kang kong) were quite meh.

Singapore is a culinary paradise, and Hainanese Chicken Rice is one of its gems. If you have ever come across the CNN Go World's 50 most delicious food, you'll see this traditional dish stands confidently at number 45. Thus, there's no reason to skip it while we were in Singapore. Wee Nam Kee Hainanese Chicken Rice restaurant was our pick. The place is located on Thomson Road in the Novena area. We've heard many good stories about this place, and the experience turned out to be great.When it comes to chicken rice in Singapore, steamed and roasted chickens are among the top. At Wee Nam Kee, the chicken is super tender and lean. It was cooked beautifully, so delicious that you can taste the moist and juicy meat on your first bite! Don't forget to make yourself the perfect dipping sauce to have the greatest flavor experience. Combining chili sauce, ginger paste and low sodium dark soy sauce, you'll make up a perfect condiment to go with this dish. Eating companion is a bowl of fluffy rice, which boosts your appetite at an instant. More importantly, a meal for two will cost you anywhere from S$10 to S$16, which is a superb price tag!Recommendation: Roasted and steamed chicken rice, soy sauce chicken riceRead our Singapore Food Guide: thecoupleeats.com/singap…
The roast pork didn't taste super fresh and the char siu skin wasn't that crispy.  The hainanese chicken was fairly standard and the shark fin soup was okay.

Per locals recommendation, it was definitely on the list of places to try Hainanese chicken rice. We were lucky and a table was just leaving when we arrived, so no long queue! I would say our meal was really good. The chicken is moist and flavorful and the rice is just as tasty. We ordered half a steamed chicken and extra sauce. Yum. Cereal prawns was also something we ordered that I've never tried before and I found it to be the balance of crunchy sweet and then savory. They made it pretty well. We also got some local veggies and a hot plate dish of veggies, shrimp, and tofu. Roast chicken was yummy too. Overall, I'd recommend wee nam kee and would come back to this location. Tip: it gets busy, so get there early so you don't have to queue too long

2nd Greatest place in Singapore for roasted Hainan Chicken.The poached (steamed) & soya Hainan Chicken is below average.Very long wait time.Poor service from badly understaffed crew.Dumpling is horrendous.Tze Char here is bad.

It was quite a long wait for the chicken and after trying it out, I would say it's pretty good, but not enough to blow me away. For anyone visiting Singapore, you must try the Hainan Chicken Rice. The fragrant rice is my favorite part (I ate 2 servings myself) and I am also a big fan of adding lots of dark soy sauce to the chicken. You should also order the sambal vegetables, which is amazing (I honestly thought the vegetables were more yummy than the chicken itself). To complete the meal, you should also order the soup of the day with it.

Delicious!!! This places was kind of hard to find. I got the half chicken with all three flavors, steam, Soyo and roasted. Their ginger garlic and hot sauce was super duper bomb. Their chicken was moist and delicious. MUST KNOW: they charge for napkins........ even the wet napkins they give you when you seat. They don't tell you... until you open it and they will automatically put it on your tab.. i felt like this was a scam. I never asked for wet napkins and they dare to charge? It was only 40cents, but considering their inconsiderate action kind of got me upset... Other than that their food wasss good.
Review for Nov2016 - very popular spot around the dinner hour, make sure to call ahead for reservations or get take out. Definitely super delicious and would come here multiple times!
Died and gone to heaven. Best Chicken and Rice I've ever had! Roasted chicken dipped in chili and dark soy sauce, BBQ crispy pork, out of this world!

If there were some alternate universe where all there was to eat was chicken rice, I think I'd be okay with that.I mean, assuming that there were a number of different places to eat said chicken rice, I feel like the basic chicken/rice/broth combo could be varied enough with the additional sauces and condiments to create enough excitement in my mouth. And let's assume I could only eat chicken rice in Singapore forever and ever... it's safe to assume that I'd be here at Wee Nam Kee at least 3 out of 7 nights stuffing their delectable fowl in my mouth... either the steamed or the roasted variety, I wouldn't be all that fussy.

I went to their Katong i12 branch and I was blown away. Before Wee Nam Kee, I frequently visited another restaurant in the area. I didn't find their rice to my liking. But Wee Nam Kee has great rice as well as great chicken. I particularly like the roasted chicken and one of their tofu dish.

Chicken and rice makes life finger lickin nice.  Wee Nam Kee is among my top Chicken and Rice places in Singapore, in part, because it's just a great gathering place for friends and family members, the service is quick and efficient, and importantly, the Chicken and rice (and sauce) are quite consistently good.  The Chicken is tender and juicy; and the rice perfectly captures the Chicken juices.

so just what goes into the sauce that drenches wee nam kee's noodles?is it just a simple combo of sweet yet savoury flavours that keeps me coming back for more??or does it contain any extract similar to the secret recipe of coca-cola???i have been hooked on coke for a good part of my life but am happy to say i'm coke free for a good 2 years plus now, ever since a life changing event that culminated in a switch to drinking alkaline water.but ever since wee nam kee moved to it's new location at united square, which by the way is fully air conditioned, better organized but most importantly easier for me to get to, i have been hooked on the sauce that drenches their noodles!it probably is this same sauce that they use to season their soya sauce chicken but my personal preference has and always will be their legendary crispy skin roast chicken.their technique has been perfected such that the crispy skin is indeed crispy whilst the integrity of the succulent flesh beneath is never compromised!a whole roast chicken is what i would order and devour.do pair that with the sauce that drenches a simple plate of al dente noodles, i would, instead of their rice.the rice from another kee, also near me, is better in my humble opinion.alas, the said sauce that drenches their noodles will keep you asking for more noodles just so you can drink more sauce!sauce is it!the only reason they do not get the fifth star is their poor service.it was the same back at novena ville and some things never change.not quite sure if they are short handed.not quite sure if they are poorly trained.you can wait for long periods after being seated, desperately waving but all in vain.is service with a smile really banned?perhaps the best way for you to get your WNK fix is to order to go?no queuing, just walk up to the counter, order, pay and go.during peak hours, even more so.a check on their website reveals delivery and catering also!hmmmm perhaps mr. wee himself will bring me the sauce that drenches the noodles?!

Hands down the best Chicken Rice in Singapore! As I said in my previous Wee Nam Kee review (for the old location), I like to get the quarter chicken + rice (instead of the standard plate of 'chicken rice') when I eat there for some extra chicken. Along with the Wanton Soup and Sambal Kang Kong... this combination makes for the perfect meal.And if you've never had chicken rice before, the condiments MAKE the meal! Yes, all three - the chill sauce, ginger and the black sauce. I know a lot of people like Tian Tian and all the other famous places as well but in my opinion, Chicken Rice really doesn't get much better than at Wee Nam Kee! This place does get crowded though - be prepared to fight for a seat during lunch / dinner rush hour. Apart from their Chicken Rice, I die for the Salted Fish Fried Rice here too (not that you normally would think of ordering anything else - but everything else is surprisingly good too)! Since they have moved to United Square, as expected, prices have definitely gone up. However, for the same great food + air-con? I'm not complaining! I'm just happy the food quality remained the same!
Really solid and good chicken rice, soup, boiled chicken, and roasted pork. Dining tip: add a bit of ginger to the soup. It'll give a bit more dimension to it

My fav place to steamed chicken and YOU TIAO!!! To complete my meal I usually ordered hot barley drinks. You will not be able to go wrong with this combination =)) Cos this place is always packed, it would be easier to come in small groups. Even when you come in a small group (2 or 3 people), be prepared to share a table with strangers. This place is really popular among locals.

Our favourite chicken rice - they are pretty good for take out as well. The rice is very fragrant and the chicken is very tender and tasty. I especially like the roasted chicken. We would also typically get the 'Tou Miao' to go with the meal. I have to say the chili sauce and the ginger is what makes this a great plate of food.

I used to not like chicken rice until I met and married a Singaporean :pThis is one of my favorite chicken rice places in Singapore, and I would highly recommend getting the roast chicken if they have it, and a side of vegetable. I would also recommend eating it. If you take away, they will often forget your vegetable dish or side dish, or whatever you ordered, because it's happened to my mother in law and brother in law numerous times. IF you do takeaway, they usually rush you because it's so busy, but I would make sure you check all the food items in your bag to make sure they don't "forget" to give you all your food.

Who knew such a simple dish as Chicken Rice could be so good! And you know what, very few, if any, do it better than Wee Nam Kee.  Wee Nam's Chicken Rice comes in two distinct forms: Steamed or Roasted. Wee Nam's speciality is undoubtedly the "Roasted" Chicken Rice. I prefer dark meat, so I usually order the Drumstick Rice. Regardless of your order, whether the regular chicken rice or drumstick rice, you are in for a treat.The roasted chicken rice delivers a crunchy skin, but yet is soo juicy on the inside. The flavours of the chicken just seem to secrete out of the skin. These chicken flavours are so good that I don't even bother to use Chilli sauce or the sweetish dark sauce that normally accompanies Singapore Chicken Rice dishes. The cilantro sprinkled on top is just heavenly.I've tried three Wee Nam Kee locations and the one in United Square is clearly the best. I'm not sure if it's the original, but it's just that much better. Service is suspect, but then again, one doesn't go to Wee Nam for the service, but rather for the food. Fair Warning: any dish outside of chicken rice could take a while to serve.The Bottom Line: Wee Nam delivers a killer Roasted Chicken Rice. If you prefer steamed Chicken Rice, Tian Tian still reigns supreme in my book. The United Square Branch is The Crown Jewel of the Wee Nam Kee franchise!

Definitely get here before 12 and you'll find a seat. When lunch time hits there will be a wait. I ordered the white (boiled) chicken rice and my sister got the dumpling soup and dry noodles. The chicken rice was good (although my favorite will always be boon tong kee) but the dumpling and noodles was surprisingly delicious.

Oh my goodness, Wee Nam Kee Chicken Rice restaurant is a solid four stars! First, let me say, this place is always packed (a very good sign) so get there early or prepare to wait.   Lucky for us, we got to the restaurant before the crazy dinner rush and were quickly shown to a table. Ten minutes later there were no open tables.  Upon seating us in the air conditioned dining room, the waitress brought water, then started us off with an amazing broth. Good thing because both of us were starved. We slurped it down pretty fast and to our amazement she came over and refilled our bowls. Very cool.Since it was just two of us, we kept it simple. We ordered, of course, the chicken rice. But the baked version. It was perfectly prepared. Moist on the inside, crispy skin on top plus a large helping of lightly flavored rice. It's easily my top five chicken rice in Singapore. The  other dish was the Venison. AMAZING. AMAZING!!! I do not know which chef whipped up this dish, but I wish I could hug him. Brilliant. Five f*ing stars for the venison. Next time I visit this restaurant, my plan is to order an extra venison to go so I can lick the plate when I am done. It's that good! Trust!

Wee Nam Kee is the one chicken rice place that, when I say it's one of my faves, the locals tend to agree with me, or at least give a slight nod of approval (as opposed to a judge-y look and an emphatic HOW I KNOW YOU.)On weekends the queue for this place is crazy, but weeknight dinners are manageable. Some complain it's a bit pricey for chicken rice, but in my opinion, it's still pretty affordable considering it's air conditioned.I've tried both their (steamed/boiled?) chicken and their roasted chicken. If you've seen me on Talk answering questions about chicken rice and local cuisine, you'll know which one I'd almost marry (*whispers* it's the roasted one!)After a year and a half on the island, I'm surprised at how I'm starting to notice the difference between everyone's recipes. I think Wee Nam Kee has the best chicken, but I stand by Boon Tong Kee's rice as the more flavorful and fragrant contender.I'm a bit wary of recommending this place for someone who's never tried chicken rice, as I'm unsure if they'd appreciate or enjoy it as much. Plus, there are no ang mo celebrity chef endorsements here. :-P This is a great location in Novena; however you can also check out their other outlet in Marina Square if you can't venture too far from CBD.

Love the chicken rice here.. I like the steam one better though the roasted one is also good. Their hainam rice is always be my fav.. The taste is rich though if i may suggest, they should choose a better type or rice to make it perfect. Tio miau (dunno how to spell it) is also one of my favorite.. Their price is like a hawker price with a very nice food A bit noisy though, would be good if they can do something to reduce the noise
Came here during lunch hours.  No wait if we wanted to share a table which was no problem with us.   The chicken and rice was very good.  Would go back just for that.  Having AC helps!!

Singaporeans are very passionate about their chicken rice. It's almost as difficult in trying to get a consensus when asking Chicagoans where to find the best deep dish pizza in the city. Everyone has their favorite chicken rice. Wee Nam Kee is one the popular choices for chicken rice in Singapore.We order half a chicken and the meat is tender. The skin over the pieces of chicken is smooth but without the gelatinous layer under the skin like at Tian Tian. At Wee Nam Kee, the chicken sits on a layer of sweet-savory soy sauce that is very tasty (at Tian Tian, a golden glaze is used instead).When it comes to choosing a personal favorite establishment for chicken rice, it is more than the chicken itself that come into consideration. The accompanying rice, chilli sauce, and ginger sauce are as important and they complete the chicken rice experience. The gold standard of rice that is part of the chicken rice experience should be fragrant (traditionally, uncooked rice is fried with chicken fat before the rice is placed in the rice cooker). At Wee Nam Kee, the rice is almost reminiscent of brown rice and there is a lack of fragrance, though the chilli and ginger sauce are a little better than just good. Overall, the chicken, chilli sauce, and ginger sauce are pretty good but the rice does not stand out here. If you want to have more than chicken rice, the kitchen here prepares other itmes such as deep fried stuffed tofu and stir-fried venison with ginger and scallions.

Prettt overrated. The only reason I'll come here and eat is because it's near my house and whenever I'm too lazy to travel this is the go to place for chicken rice. However, highly recommend whoever wants to enjoy a decent plate of chicken rice please go to Tian Tian at Maxwell. By far the best in Singapore!

Move over, Tian Tian. I never liked Tian Tian (despite all the ravings and international recognition) and good chicken rice like how I remembered it to be is a hard thing to find these days. WNK is how it should be.Go for the roast chicken. It is amazing. Succulent and juicy with the perfect roasted skin that makes you want to lick the plate. So good that we ended up ordering another drumstick.Rice is fluffy and flavorful. And I also liked that their chilli is spicier than the usual places ( which seems to be toning down the flavor to suit western palate) and they still serve it with the best kind of dark soy sauce (silky, thick, not too salty, takes forever to pour out of the bottle. Yeah!)Thanks to the yelp singapore king, I saved half of my carb stomach for their $1 plain noodles. It is a simple plate of goodness.It may be better in the old days, but for now, this one still totally hits the spot.

Good chicken rice, probably my second favorite chicken rice place in Singapore.  It also offers other dishes so you can have more than chicken rice for your meal.  They accept credit card if your bill exceeds its minimum amount for payments in credit card.

This is one of the best Roasted Chicken Rice I've ever tasted. The meat is always well cooked. It doesn't have the disgusting raw chicken taste that some chicken rice have. The skin is well roasted just the way I like it. The price is cheap as well. The only thing I don't like is the ambiance. is always crowded and noisy during lunch time. The staff makes half of the noise, banging plates and utensils everywhere. The other half is made by the customers raising their voices trying to be heard by their friends and colleagues who are just across their table. Once you get past that, then nothing's stopping you from enjoying your delicious chicken rice.

This is a classic... I have never been disappointed. One of the better Chicken Rice joints of singapore that have not only maintained the taste, but also the service. Cost wise basic restaurant prices. Be prepared to pay about $40 for 3 pax. A must try place for every tourist.

Although they do chicken rice very well (go for the fried chicken), I love the food they cook in the kitchen. Their sambal kangkong is one of the best. I also like their teochew style steamed fish and salty vegetable soup. I go to Singapore every year and I try to come here once.

Pretty nice place for chicken rice, but I guess this is due to the competition for chicken rice on that 1 corner across the Novena MRT. Ordered the Hainan rice with roast + bbq pork since I don't feel like eating chicken. The rice is fragrant and tasty, but the pork isn't that great - too dry. I guess I should've stayed with the restaurant name and ordered chicken.

address: #01-11 Chong Boon Food Centre 453A Ang Mo Kio Ave 10 Singapore 561453 Singapore
comment: This is my favorite kuay teow mee soup stall.The broth is simply delicious. It's clear but extremely flavorful, with bits of minced pork floating around. The slices of pork are also surprisingly tender, but what I look forward to even more are the fish balls, slices of fish cake, piece of abalone, and prawn. The fish cake here is the star of all the ingredients though. It's handmade and the lady even sells fish cakes later in the morning. The noodles are to the right amount of doneness such that even toward the end of the bowl, it's not soggy but still slightly springy.  Although I always order the soup version, I've heard people rave about the dry version too.There can be quite a long wait on weekends, but if so, what my mom and I would do is to place an order for take away, do some marketing, and come back just in time to pick up the order. It usually holds up quite well when you take away the soup version since the stall owners will separate the soup and the noodles.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: This place was a random find for us, but the burgers were amazing!  They are the best burgers we've had since arriving in Singapore.  The service was really friendly and the little mall was good for running the kid around while we waited for the food.  The strawberry milk shake was worth it on the way out as well!

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: I had lunch here for the first time today. I made reservations via phone. We had the wild rocket burger, mushroom and cheese burger, coconut and gula melaka milkshake, flat white, onion rings and churros waffle. We both enjoyed our burgers which came with a healthy serving of beef (you can choose how well you want it and medium was perfect for me, also a choice of fries or salad). The milkshake which my friend had was supposedly great, while I prefer my flat white stronger and less acidic. Onion rings were decent with a very tasty curry sauce on the side. I loved the churros waffles though a teensy dry, had a perfect cinnamon sugar coating. Paired with chocolate, it made for a good dessert without tasting overly heavy. Service was really good - staff were attentive and very pleasant. It was a pleasure dining here and I will be back for more. The bill was about $95 for 2 persons.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Chili crab burger - 2.5 starsDidn't like how they fried the crab (with a thick fish and chips sort of batter), and the bun was well-toasted, which made it dry as a result.Calamansi mint juice - 2 starsIt was too dilute.Hae bee hiam spaghettini - 3.75 starsThe scallops were pretty small and not terribly fresh or flavorful, but you can't argue with a well-done sambal belachan and angel hair pasta.Ambience - 5 starsThis is what I'd go for. Large, roomy, with a nice view.Service - 3.5 starsThey forgot to bring our bill.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: great service and food, located right next to Botanic Gardens MRT.there's no close (great) eateries in the northern part of Botanic Gardens, where D and I frequent with our little boy. so this restaurant is the perfect place for us to unwind after a long day visiting the children's park and walking around Singapore's version of Central park.  The restaurant, located right next to Cold Storage, has a warm and homely feel, and serves decent food- the house burger and the egg's benedict was delicious and I can't wait to come back to try the other unique gourmet burgers. But the highlight of the night was the homemade lemonade- it was served in a cute mason jar and was fresh and delish that i was wishing it came in the larger size!- and the service. Our egg's benedict came around 15 minutes later than the burger, and though we didn't make any complaint about it and frankly, we were too busy watching over the baby to even notice, the server came over and apologized for the wait and said the dish was on the house. It was just really nice and thoughtful gesture that you don't see too often in Asia. love the cozy atmosphere, love the food. perfect for dates and for families as well!

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Just happened by this place after a concert at the Botanic Gardens.  The burgers are really great, very big and cooked just right.  The mushroom is also very good.  My wife liked the turnip salad too, quite different.  It's a bit pricey though for a burger place.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Excellent burgers, always. And the churros waffle with dark chocolate dip was soooo good. Sugary, cinnamony, crisp and delicious.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Nice decoration but the price have no sense. 20$ for a burger good but not big or spectacular and for this price you must to choice salad Or fries but not both !!! Beer 17$Ok the Singapore customer have budget but they are smart as well !!! No ? ;)

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: I love this spot for its simplicity and impeccable and inviting staff. Every time I am here, I honesty feel as if I'm eating at home. Relaxing and engaging staff. I not a fan of many things on the menu. However, I frequent here for the ambiance even if it's just for a drink. Beautiful rustic building and restaurant. The fries and pumpkin salad are my usual here.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Clean, simple, good service, good burger, great beer paring, good onions rings, decent fries.I had a bacon and cheeseburger, paired with their recommended German beer and it was great. The onion rings were also quite fresh, and service was polite and they had our burgers our super quickly.Don't order the SPAM fries though, they were not especially tasty. It's upstairs on the 2nd floor if you can't find it...I think it's mostly a local place, we were the only Westerners there.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: How can I miss this spot after shopping around the cold storage beneath for so many years? This explains why. The burger is good and so are the fries. They aren't fan-f-tasting but it's those great thick potato chips great for sharing. We had a few dishes to share. Onion rings with curry mayo; otak; mushroom soup and homemade foccacia. The bread was utterly disappointing, a thin slice for sharing when we thought it came with the soup. Onion rings were a winner! Burger came fast and it took us only a few minutes to stuff our bellies. The char siew was a little too sweet for our liking. Friend describe it as eating a chocolate cake but in a meat form. Nevertheless, if you like char siew & bbq sauce, go for it. Ramlee burger was decent. With that I can only say that I'm a snob, because we are used to messy processed patty with all the silly sauces and kraft blue tub. Still, I really enjoyed the dish. Love the thai radish/cucumber salad. It was really refreshing and flavourful. Dessert was, well, bad. Sorry but I can't stand a dry cake, even after you slap it with a scoop of ice cream. Service was brilliant. Two guys running the front on a weekday, brilliant job! It's a great spot to chill out with friends and family but casual dining.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Enter Relish, a 3-year-old burger joint opened by Wild Rocket. Unlike the uppity image the parent restaurant may conjure, Relish positions itself as the "fun family homeboy" offspring of the F&B group.For mains, T had the Wild Rocket Burger ($14.50++ for 150g) which was served quite simply with arugala, Sarawak pepper cream, and sundried tomato relish, coupled with a side of chips. I can't help feeling that truffle fries, the smell of which was wafting from the next table, would've been a nicer touch to the plate.E, on the other hand, was tempted into Spaghetti Arrabiata ($17.50++). In her words, it was "really good!" which in any case, was good enough for me knowing that food is genuinely being enjoyed.I was feeling under the weather so I had to tear myself away from the meat and battered food. I picked the Butterfish in Cilantro Pesto Sauce ($26.00++). I had ordered the most lackluster (and not to mention, the most expensive) dish at the table for the night. To give credits, the fish was nicely grilled but it was rather tough - I couldn't decide if butterfish were meant to be so and it was just my Asian tastebuds being used to smooth silky fish meat. Nevertheless, the dish did not quite make its worth.A great place to head down to wind down with close friends and family. I'll say stick to the burgers.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Just happened by this place after a concert at the Botanic Gardens.  The burgers are really great, very big and cooked just right.  The mushroom is also very good.  My wife liked the turnip salad too, quite different.  It's a bit pricey though for a burger place.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: It's a little painful to pay over $100 for a plate of sweet potato fries, their Ramly-style burger, their portobello tofu burger, and 4 330ml beers. That said, the sweet potato fries were awesome, the beers (Taiwanese Lychee beer) were delicious, and the burgers satisfactory, so in terms of quality one can't really complain. It was the beers really, that pushed the bill into the 100+ mark.I love the blue cheese and pear burger here, and the only reason I didn't have that was because Marcus mentioned that the Ramly is new on the menu, and hey, I love Ramly burgers. Having tried it though, the one at the Burger Shack down the road is better. I'm not sure if the Burger Shack is still there actually. :/I've also tried their steak (pretty average), the mushroom soup (really quite tasty), and nibbled on the... dried prawn pasta from a friend. All said and done, the food here is reliable, the service usually very good, and the selection of beers is a definite pull. It's a little bit pricey, all said and done, but...They don't serve that Taiwanese Lychee beer just anywhere, and together with the blue cheese and pear burger? Mmm that's worth going back time and again.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Posh burgers, and posh pastas too.My friend raves about an "off-the-menu" lobster linguine, but I'm more of a by-the-book kinda guy, so menu items it is for me. I've had most of their burgers, and I'd say the soft-shell crab one is pretty good, and you should also try the char siew open-faced burger too... I like char siew lah. I really do. The Girlfriend likes a good smelly cheese, so she's a fan of the Blue Cheese burger... I just try not to breathe when she has that one. I just heard about a menu revamp, and apparently there's a Ramly wannabe, so that's on my list next. Eh it's Ramly leh! How not to try?One of the things I'm mad about is their onion rings, which comes with a curry dip. While most of you will read this and go... really dude? Onion rings? I say give them a go. Crispy as they should be, with REAL onion rings under that batter. Dunk it in the curry dip, and it makes all the difference. Go ahead. Do it. Do it for me. I need to watch my cholesterol levels.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: The burgers here pack a punch. I had the Blue Cheese burger which was served with a generous portion of sides, Fries. The prices for the burgers are under $20 and have quite unique flavours such as the vegeterian portobello burger. The atmosphere here is laid-back, and the staff are attentive and conscientious.My mum and I made a reservation in advance, so we didnt' really have to wait. But if you want a fuss-free dining experience, do call this place up in advance.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: A very convenient location to get to, Relish is just beside the botanical gardens MRT. Located on the 2nd floor, it's got a little view and a great ambience with a lush wooden interior. It does get quite crowded during lunch and dinner times though.The coffee here was rather disappointing. It was kind of watery and flavorless. I went there on a quiet Saturday late afternoon and there were only 2 or 3 other tables occupied, but service was slow and in attentive. The staff were more interested in talking amongst themselves. Also when I'd asked about all day breakfast, the waiter rather condescendingly said, "But you're too late. Until 4 only." Really, I was very unimpressed by his attitude and felt rather offended. I can think of at least 10 different ways be could have said that nicely, with a smile.I ordered the burger with blue cheese and poached pear and it was stunning. I really enjoyed the mix of flavors as the fresh meat patties used. Very juicy and perfectly cooked to a medium done-ness. Definitely worth a try! I hope they have better service next time i go there to try the brunch menu.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Relish is one of the better burger joints in town even if their prices veer slightly north. Food : Love the seafood burger and the Relish burger but most of all I love the alcoholic milkshakes!Ambience : Airy and casual, good place for weekend brunch Service : Hit and miss

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: When Relish first started out, it was mostly a gourmet burger place. Now with the menu re-vamp, it is more bistro-like (ie, pastas, salads) but fortunately, most of the burgers are still on the menu. I really like the beer-and-burger pairings, and am a sucker for onion rings. I don't know why more burger places don't do onion rings. OMNOMNOMAlso: save room for dessert. Their selection of cakes is awesome. Its location, by the way, is fantastic--post Botanic Gardens rambling, just come over to fuel-up!

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Im not such a fan of this place. Wild Rocket is a burger joint in the Bukit Timah area. The restaurant itself has a nice vibe and atmosphere. The menu is an interesting fusion of east and west. Those are the things its has going for them. But I was disappointed eating here. First of all-- the prices are expensive. Its almost like eating in PS Cafe or something. I ordered the vegetarian portobello mushroom burger. Disappointing to say the least. It wasnt even warm, the cheese they used seemed to be Kraft cheese slices. Just not good at all, for more that $20. I will not be going back here.

address: 501 Bukit Timah Rd #02-01 Cluny Court Singapore 259760 Singapore
comment: Gourmet Burgers are on the rise and giving fast food joints a run for their money. Offering quality meat and fresh condiments, Relish's gourmet burgers pack an explosion of flavors with every bite! Try the Ramly Burger for a truly authentic asian burger experience. Instead of the usual condiment stacking in a regular burger, all toppings including the beef patty are wrapped in a thin layered omelet, hence creating a packet of intense flavors. If you're in the mood for a western adventure, go on and give the Poached Pear and Blue Cheese Burger a shot. If you need more toppings to satisfy your taste buds, add-ons are available for small fee. Wild Rocket also serves the occasional Asian inspired pasta which might prove a little spicy for some so be sure to check with your server. And finally, my personal favorite on the menu, the Relish Deconstructed Strawberry Cheesecake. The textured layers of cookie crumble, cream cheese and fresh strawberries ensure a sweet but light ending to the hearty meal.

Lovely popiahs! Full of garlic and I'm not a garlic fan.Better than the one which for some reason (which I can't fathom) is on the Michelin Bib Gourmand list.This one sometimes has a long queue. A 30-minute wait is not uncommon when someone before you orders 20 to 30 rolls of popiah (moi included).

WHAT?????? I can't believe this place doesn't have 5 stars!!!!! The Mee Siam is outrageously mouthwateringly addictively insanely out of this world Good !!!!!! I want to marry the person making this delicious bowl of heaven!!!!! ( note to my dear husband who might stumble upon my review one day - 'relax  I'm just kidding - ish')The Mee Siam is piquantly sweet , spicy , soury all at once. When it hits your tastebuds there are firework like  explosions of flavor ! Pop rocks move aside!No no no no no I can't believe I'm living million of miles away from this place ... I'd move back  to Singapore just for this! This place also makes kick ass popiah . I should know I only ate 3 rolls of it every other day for 1 year ! Hehehehe

I love this nondescript corner eatery for its local food. The popiah is a must have. It is absolutely delish. The kueh pie tee is equally good with a crispy shell. The chili is very spicy. Beware. The laksa is very lemak (coconutty) and the mee siam is pretty spicy on its own.Oooh...and the bandung is made the traditional way with lots of evaporated milk, unlike those served in coffee shop now.

Love this small but cozy cafe setting at a corner of Coronation Plaza (2nd floor). I do not really know since when my family and I love coming to this place but we have definitely come here for awhile now.What to order from here? Mee Rebus and popiah are my two favorite dishes here. I enjoy eating the Mee Rebus sauce as it has a tangy feeling after you eat it. The portion wise is not big but for it's price (less than $5), it was worth it. I think I prefer the Mee Rebus here than to other "toast" chains. For the popiah, you might need to wait awhile before being serve. The wait gets crazy over the weekend as a lot of people seemed to only like their popiah instead of their local delicacies. For the popiah, like many newspaper articles had mentioned, it is one of the best. The ingredients made the whole popiah to be fragrant and not soggy. Depending on your tastebuds, a hint of chili sauce might increase the tastiness of the popiah itself. The price was also reasonable.If you would like to avoid the crowds, do not come during peak hours (lunch time) or weekends. The seating for this place was limited and you might need to share tables with other customers if you come alone.Another suggestion is that instead of take aways, consume it fresh (as in dining in). It definitely has different taste if you consume it straightaway or ten to fifteen minutes later. Will definitely continue to support this place. It is definitely a hidden gem in the midst of cafes along the Bukit Timah stretch.

Gonna bump up the stars here. Eh if you think the popiah is so awesome then give 5 stars lah. It really IS that awesome. Stop eating all other popiahs. Also, don't tell your friends about this place, because it's very small and the da bao queue for popiah gets very long. Just kidding. Come all the time, bring the whole kampung. It's the best popiah in the world.

This is literally my first and probably only yelp review and I'm writing it retroactively because I haven't been there in a while but it's SO fucking good. I cannot stress how much I love their popiah and how much I think of it when I'm away from home. I have a photo album dedicated entirely to their popiah and it doesn't even look that great. The pictures just remind me of how it tastes and the mouth-feel it has. But if you go please don't order 20 rolls at a time because I will actually attack you if you make me wait more than 10 minutes for my popiah (even though I WILL wait for hours and it WILL be worth it - it's just annoying).

Most people would only visit My Cosy Corner for their popiah or kueh pie ti, or else a rather average but budget Japanese rice bowl. Their popiah isn't even very cheap at $2.20, but there's no doubt that they know what they are selling, and also no wonder their popularity for it. It's main filing is a simple turnip and carrot combination, not the massive filigree of vegetables and ingredients, yet it works a treat. My favourite part of their popiah is its texture: a few other ingredients added to the mix also gives it a very nice crisp in every bite, yet the skin is soft so the filling is always fighting to break free.I haven't had anything else memorable here. My only other memory here is how rude the Uncle running the shop can be, but as a whole they do genuinely seem nicer to frequent customers, so if you think the popiah is worth coming back to, it may be worth starting to make friends too.
best popiah in town!'nuff said! SEDAP!

The name cozy corner is a misnomer- the shop is tucked away in a dusty corner of Coronation Plaza yes, but it is the furthest thing from 'cozy'. Its been around for as long as I can remember- and serves one of the best popiahs I have ever had. The radish in their popiahs are cooked to perfection- soft, tasty and appetizing. They also throw in a bunch of magic ingredients that I cant really tell- but there is something in their popiah that gives it an extra crunch (could be lard- so sinful but I don't care). One sells for $2.20 which is pretty expensive, but looking at the queue I don't think price is a factor when the fanatics are queuing for this popiah. Sometimes the popiah is made by the aunty, sometimes the uncle, it doesn't really matter because they are equally good.Their other dishes are also not too bad, but pretty expensive. I remember their Japanese food selling for as much as sushi tei's, but I really didn't like my tempura udon. The tempura was fried chinese-style- weird, heavy batter and the udon was overcooked. I also sometimes have the meesiam which I quite enjoy- tangy and spicy at the same time. The store is also very 'spiritual', and plays church music like hillsongs. I don't really have an opinion on it because it doesn't really bother me. What bothers me more is that sometimes the aunty gets really grumpy when she's busy though in a harmless way.

Go to Cosy Corner if you're craving for a decent plate of popiah. Their popiahs are delicious, but be careful when you order the spicy popiah. It might be a little spicy for those who can't take their chili.I'd go here for their oyaku don as well. It tastes alright for the price. The ramen and udon and pretty much all the other dishes are pretty meh, though. Also, there's always a shortage of seats, so you might have to end up taking away the food or (if you're a student) sit on the floor.

Student food FTW! On a school day, you'll find My Cosy Corner crowded with students from Hwa Chong, Nanyang, etc, for cheap eats. Unfortunately for us working adults, the student prices don't apply, but it's still a nice place to drop by before grocery shopping at the NTUC downstairs if you don't feel like queuing at Penang Kitchen next door.

Indeed the go to place for popiah but for me i just enjoy the fried rice with a chicken wing topped off with an egg. This was the place I used to frequent often after school with friends that stayed in the area. The small cramp sitting area makes its well "cosy" I guess. I still visit this store every now and then for a trip down memory lane plus its probably one of the stores in coronation plaza that sells food. The rest of the stores include barbers, school uniform retailers and the occasional odd shops selling a multitude of random things!

address: 628 Ang Mo Kio Ave 4 #01-86 628 Ang Mo Kio Market and Food Centre Singapore 560628 Singapore
comment: The stall was located at one end of the hawker centre. It offered zhi cha dishes, which was not easy, considering the small space it occupied. White Bee Hoon ($5/ single serving)The dish was served in soupy version with seafood such as sliced fish, la la (clams), prawns, sliced pork, and crispy pork lards in it. It looked simple but well flavoured.Sambal Sweet Potato Leaves ($6)The version here was quite dry but well flavoured with crunchy texture in the vegetables. I was expecting a wetter and softer version which I usually preferred.

There's a cute guy in this outlet if you care for cute guys.Now back to business. I like the crepes, will definitely be back. The bacon, egg and cheese crepe was delicious. It was simple, I bet anyone who can make a crepe can probably make it, but it's simplicity at its best. The cheese was ultra cheesy, with every bite you could pull the cheese out and twirl it in circles with your mouth. So chewy and addictive. The egg reminded me of the egg sandwiches my mother sometimes made for me, and bacon being bacon, can't go wrong as long as it's not chaota.My cousin ordered the seafood soup. It was served in a cup, cute. The taste was very savoury; I felt it tasted a lot like prawn soup while she felt it tasted full of clam flavour. But then again, I'm not a clam eater so she was probably right.

OK, there is no avoiding that the name is silly.  It's a phonetic spelling of the French C'est Bon which means it's good or it's nice in English.  Anyway, back to the review.   It's essentially a crepe place, and they do crepes quite well, but they have much more.  I've been here for breakfast and really enjoyed it.  The people working there were friendly and efficient.  LE PETITE COMPLET is a great way to start the day if you're up in Bishan as I was one morning.I've been back several times and will continue to go back whenever I'm in Singapore.

I've always had a weakness for thick soups, crepes and yummy salads. Thanks to Saybons, I can enjoy all three of these French classics at affordable prices and within arm's reach! Although compact in size, the eatery's jovial ambience makes it ideal for both business lunches and intimate meetings with friends. (Takeaway is available too) A hot favourite here is the Crepe, which comes in either savoury or sweet concoctions. Choose from heavy-duty ingredients like Salmon, Onions and Cheese to light fixtures such as Tuna and Capsicum. I'm not an outright sweet tooth but when cravings are concerned, anything to do with Nutella hits the target.  The "Nutty Nutella" crepe features our beloved Nutella spread sprinkled with roasted hazelnut bits for extra oomph. Don't expect too much filling in your crepe though!Don't forget to pick up the tantalising Soups, which are presented in mugs because sipping is the way to go. Personally, "Brocolli and Cheddar" as well as "Potato and Leek" remain my favourite soup flavours so far. The soups' thick, creamy texture brings comfort to my palette! For someone health conscious like me, I was pleased to find that besides these vitamin-packed soups, the eatery also serves up crunchy mini salads.

I only kinda like this place for its crepes. They've added some new things on the menu since it first started but I still prefer the crepes over the rest. My personal favourite is the Nutella crepe because hey, anything with Nutella is instantly good. Though I wish the crepes itself was a little thicker and that they'd be more generous with their fillings. The consistency is also a bit off cuz sometimes you get a really nicely done one and sometimes it's kinda crappy so it really depends on the person making your crepes. They've got escargot now too but I don't think I'll be trying that anytime soon. The place is more like a cafe than a restaurant really and they've got coffee and tea on the menu too. When I first started coming here they didn't have seats but now they've got a whole seating area that you can chill out at. Just manage your expectations when you eat here. While it's tasty, it's really just fast food in nature so don't expect to bee blown away.
had nutella and banana crepes with mushroom soup. wasn't anything to rave about.not a place to fill up your tummy, just a quick to-go bite

Saybons is a wee little cafe-ish fast food-ish spot on the 2nd floor of J8. They are slightly more expensive than, say... McDs, but cheaper than DTF. And they are yummy. Their soups are thick, hearty, and tasty -- I've tried several now and all have been great. You can even read more about each of them if you sit at one of the tables on the side. Salads are good and always fresh. I do wish they could be served in dishes for eating in, rather than taking up so much plastic. :( but they are yummy and flavorful. The chickpea avocado one is healthy and filling! Escargot! Definitely yum, if you like snails (which I do). I haven't tried all the flavours, but I tend to think simple is best, and they do it pretty well here -- so unusual for a casual franchise joint like this.So why not 4 stars? The decor is just... ugh. I really don't want to stay / sit there, even though the staff are generally friendly. The colours are too bright and seem completely in contrast to the calm, comforting food they serve here. Also, they rely far too much on disposable serving containers and such. If you are a cafe, and you have a SINK, you should serve things in dishes. I dislike contributing to the throw-away culture, especially given the wee island we are all living on. But hey, the food is good, and so I'm saying Saybons deserves 3-star decency.

Whenever I see a small steak place, I always have high hopes and expectations of the place, merely because I expect good quality meat and good cooking. The wagyu beef flank did not fail my expectation, it was tender, cooked to my liking, loved the slightly burnt sweet potato side. Tried my hubby's Aglio Olio with truffle and salad, it was a tad bland to the taste, but the spaghetti was cooked just right, firm and not whimpy.Mum commented her Rosemary spring chicken was also bland, and Dad's mixed grill was great, loved the sunny side up on it.Service is not really there as they basically just takes order amd serves food. We had to keep asking for the menu, a 3 person crew includes 2 chefs and 1 waiting staff. Apparently chefs do not hand out menu even though 1 was not cooking (yet), and just kept telling us to order at the cashier (it's a small place with 5 tables for crying out loud). Bottom line: good food, don't expect service, they are not rude, just non-chalant.

Visited Hajime for a colleagues birthday lunch treat.  There is ample space and most tables seat 3 to 4 people. We occupied the seats toward the back of the restaurant for larger groups. The waiter serving us provided us with menus with were detailed and descriptive with photos of the various types of dishes that were available. There are slips of paper where you write your order down. You then have to go to the counter to submit your order and pay. This was slightly surprising but I guess in terms of hiring employees it is more cost efficient?
